title: Mason Cox
text:
Mason Cox (born March 14, 1991) is an American-Australian professional <a href="Australian%20rules%20football">Australian rules football</a>er who plays for the <a href="Collingwood%20Football%20Club">Collingwood Football Club</a> in the <a href="Australian%20Football%20League">Australian Football League</a> (AFL). Playing as a <a href="ruckman%20%28Australian%20rules%20football%29">ruckman</a> and <a href="Australian%20rules%20football%20positions%23Full%20forward">key forward</a>, he first played Australian rules football in April 2014 before making his AFL debut two years later in April 2016. Cox had previously played basketball for <a href="Oklahoma%20State%20Cowboys%20basketball">Oklahoma State University</a> in the <a href="Big%2012%20Conference">Big 12 Conference</a> and, standing at 211 cm (6 ft 10in), is the tallest player to ever be measured at an <a href="AFL%20Draft%20Combine">AFL Draft Combine</a>.
Early life.
Cox was born in <a href="Highland%20Village%2C%20Texas">Highland Village</a>, a suburb of <a href="Dallas">Dallas</a>, <a href="Texas">Texas</a>, USA to parents Jeanette and Phil, the youngest of their three sons. He attended high school in <a href="Flower%20Mound%2C%20Texas">Flower Mound, Texas</a>. Cox was a student at <a href="Edward%20S.%20Marcus%20High%20School">Edward S. Marcus High School</a>, and was part of the school's state championship winning soccer team. <a href="Boston%20Celtics">Boston Celtics</a> player <a href="Marcus%20Smart">Marcus Smart</a> attended the same school and he and Cox would later be teammates at college.
Cox studied <a href="engineering">engineering</a> at <a href="Oklahoma%20State%20University%E2%80%93Stillwater">Oklahoma State University</a>, graduating in 2014. While studying, he started playing <a href="basketball">basketball</a> as a hobby. He initially joined the <a href="Oklahoma%20State%20Cowgirls%20basketball">Oklahoma State Cowgirls</a>' "scout team" to simulate <a href="Brittney%20Griner">Brittney Griner</a>, former <a href="Baylor%20Lady%20Bears%20basketball">Baylor University basketball</a> player. After being noticed by former head coach <a href="Travis%20Ford">Travis Ford</a>, he was asked to join <a href="Oklahoma%20State%20Cowboys%20basketball">the university's men's basketball team</a> as a <a href="Walk-on%20%28sports%29">walk-on</a>. He played a total of 57 minutes for the Cowboys, scoring seven points. One of his highlights while playing <a href="NCAA%20Division%20I">NCAA Division I</a> basketball was shutting down future <a href="National%20Basketball%20Association">National Basketball Association</a> star <a href="Joel%20Embiid">Joel Embiid</a> while defending him.
AFL career.
Cox was invited to attend the 2014 <a href="AFL%20Draft%20Combine%23US%20Combine">US International Combine</a> for potential Australian rules footballers, in Los Angeles in April 2014. After impressive performances in the skills testing he traveled to Australia for a second combine and on May 30, 2014, was signed by the <a href="Collingwood%20Football%20Club">Collingwood Football Club</a>. AFL teams <a href="Port%20Adelaide%20Football%20Club">Port Adelaide</a>, <a href="North%20Melbourne%20Football%20Club">North Melbourne</a>, <a href="Richmond%20Football%20Club">Richmond</a>, and <a href="Fremantle%20Football%20Club">Fremantle</a> were also reported as having shown interest in recruiting Cox.
Cox played for the Collingwood <a href="Australian%20Football%20League%20reserves%20affiliations">reserves</a> team in the <a href="Victorian%20Football%20League">Victorian Football League</a> (VFL) throughout the 2015 season whilst learning the game and improving his skills.
After playing well in the opening two games of the <a href="2016%20VFL%20season">2016 VFL season</a>, he made his AFL debut on April 25, 2016 in the annual <a href="Anzac%20Day%20match">Anzac Day match</a> against <a href="Essendon%20Football%20Club">Essendon</a>. Within the first 80 seconds of the match, he took his first <a href="Mark%20%28Australian%20football%29">mark</a> and scored the game's first <a href="Goal%20%28Australian%20rules%20football%29">goal</a> with his <a href="List%20of%20first%20kick/first%20goal%20kickers%20in%20the%20Australian%20Football%20League">first kick in the AFL</a>. Collingwood went on to win the match by 69 points.
On September 11, 2017, despite interest from other clubs, Cox signed a three-year contract extension, keeping him at Collingwood until the end of 2020. Cox continued his good form in the <a href="2018%20Collingwood%20Football%20Club%20season">2018 season</a>, kicking a career-high 5 goals in the <a href="Queen%27s%20Birthday%20match">Queen's Birthday match</a> at the <a href="Melbourne%20Cricket%20Ground">MCG</a> and was awarded the Neale Daniher trophy as Best on Ground.
In the <a href="2018%20AFL%20finals%20series%23First%20preliminary%20final%20%28Richmond%20vs.%20Collingwood%29">2018 Preliminary Final</a> against <a href="Richmond%20Football%20Club">Richmond</a>, he played a man of the match performance kicking three goals consecutively and taking many contested marks, Bruce McAvaney remarked "what has Collingwood unleashed" when talking about Mason's performance.
In the <a href="2018%20AFL%20Grand%20Final">2018 Grand Final</a>, he kicked 2 goals during the 3rd quarter and took many contested marks, while playing in Collingwood's loss.
Cox was seeking <a href="Permanent%20residency">permanent resident</a> status on a path towards Australian citizenship to fulfill his desire to live the rest of his life in Australia, committing to a multi-year contract at Collingwood. At the end of March 2020, he was accepted to become an Australian citizen.

Personal life.
Mason's older brothers also now play Australian rules. Nolan played the <a href="USAFL%20National%20Championships">USAFL National Championships</a> team <a href="Austin%20Crows">Austin Crows</a> and has also represented the <a href="United%20States%20men%27s%20national%20Australian%20rules%20football%20team">USA Revolution</a> national team. Austin plays for USAFL club the <a href="Seattle%20Grizzlies">Seattle Grizzlies</a>. Mason has expressed a keen interest in promoting the game at the grassroots in the US, visiting the US to support his brothers at the USAFL National Championships.
